body: • An editing error in an article about health spending led to a claim that the NHS in England had run up a record deficit of £2.45bn in the last financial year. The deficit is not for the whole of the NHS in England, but NHS trusts, which predominantly run hospitals (NHS incurs record £2.45bn deficit in England as demand outstrips funds, 21 May, page 10). • Cliveden, the National Trust property formerly owned by the Astor family, is in Buckinghamshire, not Berkshire, and it was the second Duke of Buckingham, not the first, who acquired the estate in the 17th century and fought a duel with his mistress’s husband. We also had the date of the duel wrong: it took place in 1668, not 1688 (Chamber music: giant amp filled Cliveden with sound, 19 May, page 13). • The clue for 17 across in last Thursday’s quick crossword (No 14,361, page 24, G2), “Annual London dog show”, did not tally with the solution, “Crufts”. While the dog show was formerly held in London, since 1991 it has been held at the National Exhibition Centre in Birmingham. • Other recently corrected articles include: NHS chief says Brexit would be dangerous for health service Why isn’t there a Grindr for straight people?
